title: 114_hr3284
content: The Act titled "Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015" establishes a patient registry for mesothelioma data collection and research under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the US, including incidence and prevalence. The registry will be used to track epidemiology, collect health information, and report on mesothelioma patients. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the US, including treatment outcomes, patient longevity, number of patients receiving treatment disaggregated by hospital, incidence, prevalence, factors associated with mesothelioma, and to facilitate further research. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma, including environmental and occupational factors, key demographic factors, and make non-identifiable information available for research and prevention efforts. The Secretary will collect and store information on the incidence and prevalence of mesothelioma in the United States, including demographics and other associated factors like age, race, ethnicity, sex, geographic location, and family history. The collection and storage of information on mesothelioma will include risk factors, diagnosis markers, epidemiology, and natural history of the disease. The Secretary shall consult with experts on epidemiology, prevention, detection, management, treatment, and outcomes measures for mesothelioma. This includes epidemiologists and representatives of national voluntary associations. The Secretary shall consult with experts in epidemiology, disease surveillance, national voluntary associations focused on mesothelioma, health information technology, clinicians specializing in mesothelioma, and research scientists conducting translational research. Coordination with other federal agencies is also required. The Secretary will share registry information with federal agencies like NIH, FDA, CMS, AHRQ, VA, and DoD for research purposes. Public access to registry information will be provided by the Secretary. The Secretary will make registry information available to the public and ensure stringent privacy protections. Initial reports to Congress are required within 18 months of enactment. The Secretary must submit an initial report to Congress within 18 months of the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015 enactment. The report will outline findings, future plans for the registry, and its scope. The Secretary will submit a subsequent report to Congress 4 years after the enactment of the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015, detailing the implementation of the registry, including partnerships with research and patient advocacy communities. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the Patient Registry Act of 2015, detailing the development and maintenance of the mesothelioma patient registry, the type of information collected, its use and availability, and the coordination of databases for mesothelioma information.
